D1.title: Designing a Mission-Aligned Seminar
D1.narrative:
You are preparing an upper-level interdisciplinary seminar at {{institution}}, but you're facing a challenge. Since you last taught it, students' study habits have changed. Now they are accustomed to using ChatGPT and other generative AI tools. You know most use it for brainstorming and finding sources, but the international students rely on it heavily for translation. Additionally, you suspect some students use it for writing and have been able to avoid AI detection tools by using "humanizers" and other methods designed to evade detection.

As you outline the syllabus, you consider how each possible stance on AI could cultivate {{institution_short}}'s values, including leadership in {{value1}}, {{value2}}, and {{value3}}. As you always ask when designing a course: How can you instill the excitement of your advanced topic and encourage students to use its knowledge to live virtuous and {{value4}}? You consider five positions: 1) ignoring the issue and deferring decisions; 2) prohibiting AI outright; 3) allowing limited, ethical AI use; 4) permitting AI to support much of the work; and 5) designing the course to collaborate with students using AI tools. Each, you realize, involves risks and rewards. What will you choose?

I1.title: The Decision to Maintain Status Quo
I1.narrative: You're facing a heavy workload this semester—committee work, research deadlines, and advising demands pile up. As you draft your syllabus, you decide to maintain the status quo, adding only a vague academic honesty statement: "Students are expected to submit their own work." This saves you dozens of hours of course redesign. You tell yourself you'll address AI properly next year, when you have more time. For now, you focus on the content you're passionate about teaching.

I2.title: Cheating and Complacency
I2.narrative: Midway through the semester, you notice something troubling. Student papers suddenly show uniform polish—similar phrasing, consistent formatting, and a surprising lack of the usual errors. During office hours, two dedicated students confide their frustration: "Everyone else is using AI and getting away with it. We're working so hard, and they just paste prompts." You feel caught—you don't have time to investigate every assignment, but the inequity is obvious. Trust begins to erode, and you wonder if your silence communicated approval.

P1.title: Setting the Boundary
P1.narrative: You draft your new course policy: "AI-generated text is not permitted on any assignments." You frame it as protecting academic honesty and human dignity. You also point to {{institution_short}}'s commitment to be {{motto}}, pointing out that allowing machines to think for us or do our work appears to be the opposite of this motto. Finally, you point out that many important leaders have begun to sound the alarm on the potential destructive power of AI, and if your job is to help train the "pioneers of a global civilization," then humanity should be resisting AI, not embracing it, for it is already becoming weaponized. Students nod, although many seem unconvinced. One international student reluctantly and privately asks if translation tools count, while another asks if they can use Grammarly or Microsoft Word's "algorithmic grammar correction" tools.

P2A.title: The Translation Question
P2A.narrative: A multilingual student confides: "I only use AI to translate readings so I can understand class discussion." You reaffirm your rule: each student should rely on their own effort to develop language skills. You remind yourself the policy safeguards fairness, yet you wonder if students continue to use AI. You take more time to check the AI detection tools, and two assignments raise concerns, but their probability scores are too low to confront the students. Participation drops, and you sense growing distance. At the same time, one student tells you during office hours that she appreciates your stance because she has resisted using AI, and feels that when her classmates use it, they are not learning and gain an unfair advantage.

P3A.title: The Enforcement Semester
P3A.narrative: You implement AI detection software and restate strict consequences. Midterm, a false flag occurs — a student accused of AI use insists on innocence. The process consumes hours of investigation alongside meetings with the Dean of Students about due-process and dignity. Students stop visiting office hours; compliance rises, curiosity drops.

P4.title: Outcome: Integrity Preserved, Dialogue Lost?
P4.narrative: By the end of your course, your records show near-perfect compliance. But course evaluations describe your class as "serious, but tense" and one student remarks "I had trouble dismantling all the tools, like the automatic grammar checker and I don't think all of my classmates turned theirs off." You reflect: was integrity upheld, or did you and your students play "cat and mouse" all semester, distracting from the excitement you have previously shared in your field? Have your choices supported {{institution_possessive}} vision of graduates leading ethical lives?

B1.title: Designing the New Course
B1.narrative: You're drafting a syllabus for a new upper-level interdisciplinary seminar at {{institution}}. You know that students already use AI for translation, brainstorming, and writing support. Rather than ban it, you design a short unit on "Responsible AI Use" that ties directly to {{institution_short}}'s value of fostering leaders of {{value1}} who can engage difference with empathy. Students will practice writing with and without AI, comparing their processes and reflecting on what they learn.

B2A.title: Ethical AI Workshops
B2A.narrative: Week three. Students bring examples of AI output alongside their own writing. They identify what AI captures — and what it misses. Discussion turns lively: "How do we know when AI's help becomes substitution?" You surface {{institution_short}}'s mission and values, asking which uses cultivate leaders of culture in the community. You realize they're not just learning writing — they're learning judgment.

B3A.title: Refining the Policy
B3A.narrative: Together, the class revises its "AI Use Agreement." Students agree to cite AI assistance, reflect on their process, and take responsibility for final ideas. You highlight alignment with {{institution_short}}'s aim to foster leaders of culture who act with integrity. You notice improved confidence in emerging writers and fewer integrity concerns. Still, updating and clarifying the policy each semester takes time. Some colleagues worry: "Won't this gray area confuse students?"

B4.title: Outcome: Ethical Clarity Through Dialogue
B4.narrative: By term's end, students submit reflective essays describing how AI shaped their thinking. Most express gratitude for being trusted to decide responsibly. A few still wish for simpler rules, but many highlight new awareness: "I learned not just what AI can do — but what I can do with it." You guide them to name which SUA values their choices advanced: {{value1}}, culture, {{value3}}, or {{value4}}. You sense the course has fostered something deeper than compliance: wisdom linked to mission.

E1.title: Rethinking the Assignment
E1.narrative: You sit at your desk drafting the syllabus for your new upper-level interdisciplinary course. You know students already use AI for brainstorming and translation. Instead of policing that reality, you wonder: "What if I invited AI use as part of the process itself?" You rewrite a major paper assignment into an "AI-Reflection Portfolio," where students must document prompts, evaluate AI output, and annotate what they learned about thinking itself. You frame the experiment as cultivating leaders of {{value3}} who can resolve complex problems with creativity and care.

E2A.title: First Iteration
E2A.narrative: Students experiment with AI during early drafts. Some produce nuanced reflections; others hand in work too dependent on the tool. In discussion, you model critical use: showing how to question AI's assumptions. The room fills with excited and uncertain energy. One student says, "I've never thought so much about how I write." Another links the work to preparing for peacebuilding dialogues abroad.

E3A.title: The Assessment Challenge
E3A.narrative: Grading portfolios takes longer than expected. You realize authentic work requires new evaluation criteria, and growth, insight, and self-reflection now matter more than grammar or format. A peer asks, "Isn't this subjective?" You reply, "Maybe, but so is learning." By mid-semester, students begin referencing AI critically in discussions about ethics, bias, and creativity, connecting the seminar to {{institution_possessive}} vision of graduates leading {{value4}}.

E4.title: Outcome: Innovation and Depth
E4.narrative: At semester's end, students present reflective projects titled "What I Learned From My AI Mistakes." Their work is messy, honest, and profound. Some still rely too much on the tool, but most articulate a clearer sense of authorship. You feel both exhausted and inspired. When you share at a {{writing_center}} AI workshop, a colleague says, "This feels like the future of {{institution_short}} education: humanistic, creative, responsible." Another confides later on that he doesn't have the time and hasn't gotten the training to repeat your experiment in his course.

C1.title: Opening the Dialogue
C1.narrative: You begin the semester with an open question: "How should we, as a learning community, engage with AI?" Instead of dictating rules, you invite students to share experiences — how AI has helped, hindered, or confused them. Together, the class drafts an "AI Reflection Charter" that commits to transparency, curiosity, and mutual respect, explicitly linking the work to {{institution_short}}'s mission of fostering leaders of {{value3}} and {{value1}}.

C2A.title: Shared Experimentation
C2A.narrative: Each week, students log one AI interaction — a prompt, a response, and their reflection on it. In class, small groups analyze where the tool enhanced or hindered their thinking. Surprisingly, students begin to critique AI's biases and limits more deeply than expected. You frame the practice as nurturing leaders of culture in the community who can steward technology with care.

C3A.narrative: Colleagues hear about your approach and invite you to a workshop on AI in writing and pedagogy. You share anonymized student reflections, both breakthroughs and confusions. Another professor worries about workload: "How do we grade process fairly?" You agree: collaboration requires new assessment norms. The group plans a small cross-course study grounded in {{institution_short}}'s values. You worry that this will require 10 hours of work, time you don't have, but it feels necessary.

C4.title: Outcome: Dialogue Becomes the Curriculum, But is it Sustainable?
C4.narrative: By semester's end, your class talks about AI as easily as about literature or ethics. Students report feeling trusted, and more responsible as a result. Faculty peers adapt your reflective logging model. The project closes with a sense of optimism, not that you've solved AI in education, but that you've learned to face it together. Still, you know not every course or instructor has the time for this level of mentoring and you worry that the technology is changing much faster than professors and the university can adapt.
